An aircraft has a hydraulic system with a normal operating pressure of 3000 psi.

options.text: used after a N-1 (one engine flame-out) during flight.
a turbine that drives the N2 gearbox.

questions.query: The hydraulic system pressure of a large transport aircraft is regulated by the...

options.text: system accumulator whose piston can move up/down by gas pressure to maintain the system pressure.
pressure relief valve parallel to the pump relieving any excessive pressure to the pump inlet.
engine pump itself through a movable swash-plate controlled by a springloaded piston.
reservoir air pressure regulator using regulated bleed-air.

options.text: the camplate (or swashplate) angle of the pump.
the air pressure on top of the hydraulic reservoir.

options.text: depending on the air pressure on top of the hydraulic reservoir.
always one third (1/3) of the hydraulic system pressure.

questions.query: To prevent the loss of the flight control system during a hydraulic leak...

options.text: the hydraulic system is equiped with a power transfer unit.
as an alternative to hydraulic actuators, the primary flight control surfaces are also connected to electric- and pneumatic actuators.
multiple, independent hydraulic systems may pressurise the actuators of the primary flight control surfaces.

questions.query: One of the functions of a hydraulic accumulator is to...

options.text: compensate for fluid loss in case of a leak.

linear actuators facilitate alternate gear extension better than hydraulic motors.
hydraulic motors are less reliable than linear actuators.

questions.query: If the main pump of the hydraulic system fails, the hydraulic system will be...

options.text: pressurised by another system by transferring hydraulic fluid from another system.

questions.query:

options.text: hydraulic pumps are not in operation and the accumulator may be used to supply the (parking) brakes.
there is no electricity to keep the indicator needle at the correct value.
accumulator pressure is always one third of the normal hydraulic system pressure.

questions.query: Why is the hydraulically operated, horizontal stabiliser normally operated by a rotary actuator, and not by a linear actuator?

options.text: Linear piston actuators move to an undetermined position after a hydraulic failure.

leakage of nitrogen in the most compressed leg.
too little oil in the least compressed leg.

options.text: a piston in a cylinder filled with a liquid and a gas.

questions.query:
Idle rpm is based on having just sufficient power for taxiing purposes.

During the descent from cruise flight-level to the initial approach-fix, when no power is required, one also expects an idle power setting.

However, during the (final) approach, many aeroplanes with a gasturbine engine use a slightly higher power setting.

The reason for this is that during the approach...

options.text: one must be prepared to make an evasive manoeuver to stay clear of conflicting traffic.
the engine must compensate the extra drag caused by the landing gear and the flaps/slats.
one must be prepared to make a go-around which requires the engine to be at 100% in 5 seconds.
the engine driven hydraulic pumps must work harder to fulfil to the pressure demand.

questions.query:
Idle rpm is based on having just sufficient power for taxiing purposes.

During the descent from cruise flight-level to the initial approach-fix, when no thrust is required, one also expects an idle thrust setting.

However, during this descent, many aeroplanes with a gasturbine engine use a slightly higher thrust setting.

The reason for this is...

options.text: to have sufficient bleed-air for cabin pressurisation.
the capacity of the accessory gearbox is too low to drive all consumers.
to have sufficient oil pressure for cooling and lubrication.
with a higher thrust setting the aircraft can descend faster.

options.text: make sure sufficient fuel is kept in the tanks for the remainder of the flight.
prevent prolonged high structural loads and vibration levels on engine and airframe.
increase engine life because engines wear more at higher rpm's and temperatures.
account for oil hiding which may occur when egines run at full power for more than five minutes.

Ma is high, Vje is low and TAS is high.
Ma is high, Vje is high and TAS is low.
Ma is low, Vje = low and TAS is high.
